item.title: Hong Kong Police Arrest Activists Over Social-Media Posts
item.description: A newly formed national-security police squad arrested four students on Wednesday for alleged secessionist activities on social media, the first such swoop on opposition activists since China imposed the controversial legislation four weeks ago.

item.title: Belarus Detains Alleged Russian Military Contractors Ahead of Presidential Vote
item.description: Authorities in Belarus detained almost three dozen Russian nationals they say are military contractors who intended to destabilize the country ahead of the coming presidential election, in an incident that reflects increasingly strained relations between Minsk and Moscow.

item.title: China Hacked Vatican Ahead of Negotiations, U.S. Cybersecurity Firm Says
item.description: A Chinese-state-backed group recently hacked into Vatican computers on the eve of important negotiations with Beijing, according to a U.S. cybersecurity firm.

item.title: Pentagon to Move Nearly 12,000 U.S. Troops From Germany
item.description: The U.S. military plans to move nearly 12,000 troops from Germany, relocate its major European headquarters to Belgium, and send F-16 fighters to Italy, to implement President Trump’s decision to shrink the U.S. military footprint in the NATO ally.

item.title: Turkey Adopts New Law to Police Dissent on the Web
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s government’s new powers give it more leverage to press social media companies to remove content it doesn’t like, sending a chill through the country’s human-rights activists and dissidents

item.title: China's New Tool to Chase Down Fugitives: American Courts
item.description: Beijing is turning to lawsuits to pressure expatriates to return home and face corruption charges.
